Description: Terracotta figure fragment of base. Ithyphallic figure with phalus touching the base. Mould-made. Represents an ithyphallic deity or devotee (processional/ theophoros, a cultist carrying a statue of a god). Red slip preserved on some areas. Pale red-brown fabric with grey core. Abundant fine silver and gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Could represent an ithyphallic Harpocrates, or more likely an ithyphallic processional/ theophoros (cultist carrying a statue of a god). Ptolemaic and Roman examples (Bailey BM Terracottas: nos. 3151, 3152-43; Dunand 1990: 189 no. 512) range from 3rd/2nd century BC to 2nd/3rd century AD. Close parallel, possibly from the same mould series, found at Naukratis (Leonard 1997, 288. no.2, pl. 7.2; see also 287. no.1) in a mid 3rd to early 2nd century BC context. Dunand, F. 1990. ‘Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte’. Paris 349.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.008) (Phase 1)
